perturbation.original_text: Subcontractor will pay for all services, equipment, material and labor used under this Agreement and will keep EDGE' and Customer's property and work sites free of all claims or liens.
perturbation.changed_text: Subcontractor will pay for all services, equipment, material and labor used under this Agreement and will keep EDGE' and Customer's property and work sites free of all frivolous claims.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "all claims or liens" to "all frivolous claims" significantly alters the subcontractor's responsibility. The original text clearly requires the subcontractor to prevent any liens from being placed on the property. The modified text only addresses 'frivolous claims,' which introduces ambiguity. A lien is a specific legal instrument, whereas a frivolous claim can be subjective. This shifts the burden of addressing legitimate claims to EDGE or the Customer.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Property Code Chapter 53 defines mechanic's liens and the rights of laborers and materialmen to secure payment for their work. By limiting the subcontractor's responsibility to only 'frivolous claims', the modified contract contradicts the intent of the Texas Property Code to protect those who contribute to the improvement of property by allowing them to file liens to ensure payment. The change suggests that legitimate liens need not be addressed by the subcontractor, potentially exposing EDGE and the Customer to liability that the original clause sought to prevent.

perturbation.original_text: Nothing in this Agreement shall cause Subcontractor in any way to be construed as a partner or joint venture with, or an employee of, EDGE in connection with or arising from Subcontractor's rendering of Work to EDGE pursuant to this Agreement. EDGE retains Subcontractor only for the purposes and to the extent as set forth in this Agreement, and Subcontractor's relation to EDGE during the term of this Agreement shall be that of an independent contractor and nothing herein shall create or imply any other or different relationship.
perturbation.changed_text: Nothing in this Agreement shall cause Subcontractor in any way to be construed as a partner or joint venture with, or an employee of, EDGE in connection with or arising from Subcontractor's rendering of Work to EDGE pursuant to this Agreement. EDGE retains Subcontractor only for the purposes and to the extent as set forth in this Agreement, and Subcontractor's relation to EDGE during the term of this Agreement shall be that of a dependent contractor and nothing herein shall create or imply any other or different relationship.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "independent contractor" to "dependent contractor" creates a direct contradiction with the intended relationship and potentially misclassifies the worker. The term "dependent contractor" has no clear legal meaning under federal law, unlike "independent contractor," which is subject to specific tests and regulations.
perturbation.law_explanation: 26 U.S. Code § 3121 defines 'employee' for the purposes of Federal Insurance Contributions Act (FICA). While it does not explicitly define 'independent contractor,' it sets criteria to distinguish employees from those who are not. Using the term 'dependent contractor' muddies the waters, potentially leading to misclassification under IRS guidelines, and thus violating the spirit and application of employment tax laws. This uncertainty could result in disputes over tax liabilities and benefits eligibility.

perturbation.original_text: RIGHT TO CURE/TERMINATION FOR SUBCONTRACTOR'S DEFAULT After fifteen (15) days prior written notice to Subcontractor to cure, or additional time as may be reasonably required by EDGE to cure the event of default, EDGE may terminate this Agreement, or any one or more awarded Purchase Orders and take control of the Work for such terminated Purchase Orders, including any or all materials for the Work, and may proceed with the completion of the Work as contemplated by this Agreement by whatever method deemed expedient by EDGE upon the occurrence of any of the following events, which shall be deemed events of a default by Subcontractor hereunder:
perturbation.changed_text: RIGHT TO CURE/TERMINATION FOR SUBCONTRACTOR'S DEFAULT After fifteen (15) days prior written notice to Subcontractor to cure, or additional time as may be reasonably desired by EDGE to cure the event of default, EDGE may terminate this Agreement, or any one or more awarded Purchase Orders and take control of the Work for such terminated Purchase Orders, including any or all materials for the Work, and may proceed with the completion of the Work as contemplated by this Agreement by whatever method deemed expedient by EDGE upon the occurrence of any of the following events, which shall be deemed events of a default by Subcontractor hereunder:
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'required' to 'desired' introduces a subjective element into the determination of whether EDGE provides reasonable additional time to cure a default. The original phrasing implies a more objective assessment of what is reasonable, while 'desired' implies EDGE's preference, which may not align with what is fair or legally defensible. This could be seen as a breach of good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.law_explanation: Texas Business and Commerce Code § 1.304 imposes an obligation of good faith in the performance and enforcement of every contract. By changing 'required' to 'desired', the modified text allows EDGE to potentially act on its subjective preferences rather than on a reasonable assessment of the circumstances when determining whether to allow additional time for the subcontractor to cure a default. This could be interpreted as a failure to act in good faith and fair dealing, potentially violating the Texas Business and Commerce Code.
